title: Eat The InvadersHost Tony Armstrong — with the help of scientists, land carers, an artist and a chef — investigates different invasive species across Australia and the various strategies being used to manage their populations. goes here
subject: Geography

subject: Geography

title: Eat the Invaders: New food industriesTony Armstrong investigates the possibility of creating a sustainable camel meat industry in Australia as a solution to controlling their population numbers. Duration: 1 minute 55 seconds1m 55s

title: Eat the Invaders: The taste testTony Armstrong interviews children in Winchelsea, Victoria, about their thoughts on eating rabbit, and he keeps them company while they taste rabbit for the first time!Duration: 2 minutes 27 seconds2m 27s

subject: Geography

title: Eat the Invaders: Cane toadsTony Armstrong discusses why cane toads are considered an invasive species in Australia. In this video, he visits a group of women in Boonah, Queensland, who dedicate their free time to catching cane toads to control their population.Duration: 57 seconds57s

title: Eat the Invaders: CarpIn this video, Tony visits Coorong (Kurangk) in South Australia. He speaks to commercial fisherman Glen Hill about carp while fishing on the Murray River.Duration: 1 minute 34 seconds1m 34s

subject: Geography

title: Thylacoleo: The wild cardDid Australia's fierce marsupial predator Thylacoleo carnifex have the most powerful bite of any living or extinct mammal? How do palaeontologists use fossils to answer this question? Duration: 5 minutes 29 seconds5m
subject: Geography

title: Procoptodon: King of roosWhy is Australia's extinct kangaroo, Procoptodon goliah, called the T-rex of roos? What fossil evidence caused palaeontologists to give it that nickname?Duration: 5 minutes 52 seconds5m

title: Genyornis: Gigantic fun!What is the difference between Australia's extinct flightless bird Genyornis newtoni and an emu? What else do we know about these giant megafaunal birds?Duration: 6 minutes 7 seconds6m

subject: Geography

title: Finding Thylacoleo fossils in cavesDr Liz Reed loves finding fossils, and she loves caving. subject: Geography

title: Getting into GenyornisDr Phoebe McInerney and Associate Professor Trevor Worthy are palaeontologists who study the fossils of extinct birds. subject: Geography

title: This Place: The Journey of the Bogong MothsMungabareena means a "special meeting place" in Wiradjuri language. People would meet there on their way to Mt Bogong to collect Bogong moths and return to Mungabareena to feast on them.Duration: 2 minutes 41 seconds2m 41s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: How the Black Swan Gave Maroochydore its NameKabi Kabi man Kerry Neill shares the Aboriginal Dreaming story behind popular tourist destinations on the Sunshine Coast in Queensland.Duration: 3 minutes 25 seconds3m 25s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Boat RockThe land surrounding Berrigan is flat as far as the eye can see — except for one rocky out crop hidden down a dirt road and surrounded by farmland.Duration: 2 minutes 49 seconds2m 49s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Mugincoble — An Ancient Gathering PlaceMugincoble is a sacred meeting place for the Wiradjuri nation but is now private property.Duration: 3 minutes 43 seconds3m 43s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Bung Yarnda — Camping WatersBung Yarnda (Lake Tyers) has a rich history as being a fishing, feasting and camping place for Gunai clans in east Victoria.Duration: 3 minutes 48 seconds3m 48s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Language on CountryWarrgamay place names provide a wealth of history and knowledge of Country.Duration: 4 minutes 26 seconds4m 26s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: The Yiwarra of the AncestorsNgalia man Kado Muir takes us down the Yiwarra to the Patapuka.Duration: 2 minutes 54 seconds2m 54s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Bumbi, Balgan and the Budawang PeopleBalgan, otherwise known as Pigeon House Mountain, is a sacred place from which many stories come from.Duration: 6 minutes 6m
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Big Rock — WalgaWalga Rock has one of the largest galleries of Aboriginal rock paintings in Western Australia.Duration: 4 minutes 4m
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Mallacoota — Sacred, White, Pipe ClayIn southern Yuin land, three rivers form a junctionDuration: 2 minutes 37 seconds2m 37s
subject: Geography

title: This Place: Bila to the GaruwaIn Birpai Country, the Gathang language is spoken. It has two words for river, "bila" and "dungang".Duration: 3 minutes 36 seconds3m 36s
subject: Geography

title: Many Lands, Many Seasons, Ep 3: Tiwi IslandsHost Rulla Kelly-Mansell travels to Milikapiti on the Tiwi Islands in the Northern Territory to discover how the students mark the Tiwi seasons.Duration: 9 minutes 8 seconds9m
subject: Geography

title: Your Planet: Nyarrpararla Malaju? (Where Have All the Mala Gone?)The rufous hare-wallaby, also known as the mala, is a powerful ancestor in Warlpiri people's Jukurrpa, or Dreaming.Duration: 9 minutes 53 seconds9m
subject: Geography

title: Your Planet: BabanilFilmmaker Marlikka Perdrisat expresses her tender connection to Country in this documentary, which shows that a connection to Country is available to everyone who loves and cares for a place.Duration: 7 minutes 8 seconds7m
subject: Geography

title: Your Planet: The Oyster GardenerYear 12 student and aspiring marine biologist, Jolie May, embarks on a school community project to reinvigorate the oyster populations in the Noosa River.Duration: 10 minutes 54 seconds10m
subject: Geography

title: Your Planet: After the SmokeThis film documents the impacts of a fire at Hazelwood mine in the Latrobe Valley in 2014.Duration: 9 minutes 53 seconds9m
subject: Geography

title: First Weapons: AmerrThe amerr (pronounced ah-mud-da) is an extraordinarily versatile weapon.Duration: 5 minutes 10 seconds5m
subject: Geography

title: First Weapons: Leangle Club and Parrying ShieldThe leangle (pronounced lea-ung-gal) and parrying shield that Trevor Kirby and Brendan Kennedy made on Wadi Wadi Country are put to the test.Duration: 5 minutes 3 seconds5m
